page.title: 17HAWARDEN CASTLE
page.content: The hill on which the castle stands forms a stronghold jutting out towards the Dee estuary in the south east.Hawarden was the Northern gateway into Wales,the Romans must have travelled this way into north Wales. The hill is known to hav4 been used as a Welsh fortress during the centuries of the Roman occupation.It was captured when the Saxons invaded many centuries later. The Welsh name Penerlag means "the head of the marsh".The Saxon name of Hawarden or Hawardyn means "the high enclosure", it is found in the Doomsday Book of 1086.The Saxons built a timber structure on top of the mound and defendedthe slopes with wooden fences. At the time of the Norman invasion the area was in the possession of Edwin of Mercia.After the invasion the land was granted to Hugh Lupus Earl of Chester.
